name: The Standard at Ann Arbor
review_text: From my experience visiting people here, it was absolutely awful. Between the several times I visited, countless problems occurred. The gym, lobby, and study rooms were completely trashed from flooding that occurred because the staff kept the temperature too low. The gym was out of service both times I visited which was 2 months apart. On top of this, the power in most of the rooms barely worked. The outlets didn't function which prevented any charger or lights to work with the exception of the one overhead light. Clearly, the building was built horribly. From my understanding, utility bills were several hundred dollars per person per month which is the most outrageous expense I've ever heard. Next, the hot tub/pool was "out of service" pretty much the entire year. There was no explanation for why it was unusable and remained untouched and unfixed until pretty much the last week of classes. The structural elements of this place were ridiculous. For being a newly built apartment building, this place looked like a trashed several decade old build. Walls were cracking and separating from the floor. Also, from the burst pipes I previously mentioned, several tenants' rooms were completely destroyed. From the individuals I talked to, it sounded like they were promised to have their rooms fixed within a couple months. As it turns out, the horrible management failed to have any desire to follow through. Ultimately, these individuals never got to return to their apartments. These ruined parts of the building were essentially a construction site the entire year. Loud fans tried to air out the smell of mildew and paint. Cardboard and dust covered the floors and walls. I'm so glad I wasn't one of the tenants here. I was staying with friends for what added up to be maybe 3 weeks. Those 3 weeks enlightened me to just had bad a residence and a management team can be. The workers were unresponsive and rude. They pretended everything was fine with the apartment while things were clearly in disrepair. From what I heard and saw, maintenance orders went unanswered and unresolved for months. It's insane how much they charge for this place. I would never live here.

I would encourage your friend who is a resident to reach out to our staff to address any of their concerns further. Here is our contact information info@thestandardannarbor.com, (734) 391.6980.

name: The Varsity
review_text:
I've stayed at The Varsity throughout my junior and senior years at UM. I would be inclined to give a 5-star review, but truth is there are some improvements and critiques.

Critiques:
-The gym itself is fairly nice, but there is certainly some equipment that has been missing/lost for quite some time. Notably, there are dumbell weights that are missing their counterparts.

-Monthly rates have been increasing every year and I've been told that tenants have to start paying for utilities now. This would come out to about a $200/month rate hike since when I first leased. I understand that housing in general is increasing in the area, but the rates here have been rising too fast compared to the building's age and amenities.

-I've heard that the leasing office has been cancelling leases for the next academic term because some current residents have decided to re-lease last minute. This is very unfair for those who have signed the lease a long time ago, only to get notified that their lease is now void. I hope that they get the application fee reimbursed at least.

The positive:
-The staff are very friendly and approachable! They're always willing to help out.

-The apartment units themselves are pretty nice and spacious. The sound insulation is also better than other nearby apartments (although not perfect).

-Prime location, close to Central Campus.

-Overall nice amenities. Gym has two floors that separate cardio and strength training. 13th floor lounge is also very nice, it has a pool table, ping pong table, and a balcony area.

In general, I've really enjoyed staying at the Varsity these past two years. Management did a great job of roommate matching. I would extend my lease if I wasn't graduating.

name: The Varsity
review_text:
The facilities themselves are very nice. However, a big con is that the lounge hours are only until 9PM which is a big inconvenience and one of the only comparable apartment buildings in the area with such a restriction.

Furthermore, there has been equipment missing at the gym for a year now. The 15 lbs and 10lbs dumbbells are missing their pairs, and these are very commonly used weights, and there are not enough plates for all the equipment that use them.

Moreover, the management is not very reasonable and unwilling to listen to the community when it comes to amenities and such. They can also be condescending when asking questions.

Lastly, my friends had signed a lease and paid the security deposit and then it wasn't until MARCH that they were told that they were not going to be able to be housed because more people renewed than they were expecting and they had to scramble to find housing since March is very late in the housing cycle for students in Ann Arbor.

Definitely will not be renewing the lease, can find better places in the same location for comparable prices

During the process of trying to get it fixed, we brought it to management's attention that we were paying for the use of a laundry machine and needed a solution about where to do laundry because we were running out of clean clothing. Their response was "I don't know what to tell you." I have lived in a different high rise building so I assure you that this is not the standard for management in Ann Arbor. Live anywhere else.

name: The Varsity
review_text:
I subleased this place for summer, and I cannot wait to get out of here.
I've had so many issues during the 3 months that I lived here, that I don't even know where to begin.
On my first night I could not fall asleep because of the terrible whistling sound make by the bathroom fan. It was dirty as hell so the air could not come through. Also, the bedroom window was really tiny and so dirty that I could barely see any sun light. The next morning I went to the manager and asked if she could send someone to clean the fan and the windows. Of course I tried doing it myself, but the windows and the fan cover were locked. From the manager, I learned that they clean windows only once (!) a year in July. I saw people cleaning the windows a couple weeks ago, but apparently they only clean the front of the building. Today is July 21, and as you can see in the pic my windows are still dirty (I cleaned it a bit where I could reach with my hand).As for the fan, she suggested me to clean it myself. I dont have a skrewdriver, so I had to get used to that terrible sound or just turn the AC off.

Then, the person I subleased the apt from made a payment thinking he was still responsible for them. It turned out, I was supposed to make it, so I did. But that poor guy still cannot get his money back because Varsity returns payments only via checks. The guy is in another country, so he won't see his 1.2k refund any time soon.

Then I got my apartment flooded. Good thing I was nearby that day so I randomly came in for lunch. The hallway was full of water and the alarm was going off but no one cared. I ran downstairs, found the manager, and she sent people over to me. The maintenance crew stopped the leakage and removed water. I was left alone there to deal with the all the dirt, the soaked carpet and my wet belongings. The Varsity team didn't even bother to ask if my stuff was OK.

Today my guarantor has informed me that he received a letter called "Demand for possession", in which Varsity threatened to sue him because I did not pay my rent. To say I was confused and embarrassed is to say nothing, because I did submit my payment on time. I had to conduct a full-scale investigation to figure out what happened. It turned out that Varsity did not attempt to charge my bank account until mid-July. I did not know that, and was assuming my rent was paid so made a few other payments. So by the time Varsity actually charged me, there were a few dollars less than needed on my account, and the payment was returned. Neither the Varsity team nor their electronic payment system had contacted me to inform about that. The only thing I received right after submitting my payment was the confirmation of successful payment. This resulted in embarrassment and a $30 fine.

These are just a few of the things that happened in those 3 months that I lived here. I would not recommend anyone renting this place. I posted the photos of what the place really looked like. Check them out. Common areas  (that's why I gave it 2 stars) and the model apartment look great, but don't be fooled by it.

I Paid for the Top Floor Apartment ($100 More), however, upon arrival they tried to move me into a floor below it. After much discussion, they found their mistake and moved me into my top floor apartment which had a filthy floor and reeked of moth balls. I couldn't stand it, no matter what we sprayed the smell stayed. Finally, we found a box of moth balls in our kitchen cabinet. During my first conversation with Varsity Management regarding them putting me in the wrong room, I asked them to switch their records for my mailbox, as I was expecting an important piece of mail. They did not do this, and that important piece of mail had to be re-sent. I checked my new mailbox and saw that the names had never been changed. I informed them of that and they told me that the post office puts the names their as a courtesy and didn't have to do it and that it was my responsibility to change the names - as if I was suppose to know that without them telling me.

After many months of more quietly hating this place and having given up on them being helpful at all, my bathroom started to fall apart. First, the sink lost its temperature control. Up came the genius maintenance staff to walk around the bathroom, turn a knob and declare it fixed. Nothing changed of course, the temperature control was the same. I had them come back up the next day and thank god my roommate was there to hold the maintenance staff's hand. He told him that the issue was happening in his bathroom and the kitchen to. "it must be the cold water pressure". He adjusted it, and now the sink has the same lack of temperature control in the opposite direction (Too cold). Afterwards, they did not follow up. A few days later, my shower went on the fritz. The water pressure and temperature varied throughout my shower and the drain stopped functioning. They were able to unclog the drain, but the shower itself is still not right. Once again, no follow up.

I emailed the manger to express my anger with the entire situation and asked that he not only take care of my bathroom, but also take care of my cable that has been out for 8 months. At first he was apologetic, however, the conversation turned when the manager mentioned that I had previously responded to 2 survey follow-ups regarding how well their maintenance staff did on their repairs with ALL 5 Stars. I assured him that could not be correct because I was very upset every time and would NEVER have given them 5 stars on anything. Clearly they had been writing their own follow-up survey reviews. Very smart!

Finally, with my bathroom falling apart, cable after 9 months of waiting, and many many other lies and mistakes, I walked into my apartment, just 1 day after the cable had been fixed. I thought, man is it hot in here! I looked at the A/C and it read 78 degrees and the service button was blinking. "Crap! This place sucks." Well, I'll call maintenance and get them up here...I call the listed maintenance number, the same as the leasing office, front desk number, and a few other numbers on their contact sheet, and get the voicemail.

Please do not make the same mistake I made. Do NOT live at varsity apartments in Ann Arbor, MI. They will lie their faces off and will never work their asses off to make you happy. You're a rent check and nothing else. There are much better deal for the amount of money they ask. This place is a nightmare, the staff is incompetent, snotty, and purposely unhelpful.

name: Hub Ann Arbor
review_text:
After being a resident over the past year, I can honestly say that living in the Hub was a huge mistake. There have been countless issues that to this day are unresolved.

First: Management. This place has changed management several times over the year, and even though it has gotten better, it is nowhere near where an apartment needs to be. Maintenance is helpful in getting issues fixed I will say. If you go to the office with an issue, good luck. Not only will you be treated like you are idiotic and wrong they never seem to be able to help, such as the case when I was charged a late fee because I had to alter my direct deposit amount to pay the water bill. You pay a whole month’s rent (which is outrageous for what you get) to move in at the very end of August. They allow for maintenance to come in without properly notifying you. I have walked out of my room to find maintenance working on things they did not alert us about at the early hours of the morning. The account in which you enroll in automatic payments is not ran by the Hub and therefore they cannot fix any issues with the program, which there are countless.

Second: The building. To summarize how little issues get fixed, the main wood door of the building was removed in late February and still has yet to be placed back. This is a huge security issue, not to mention we have no real security at the door aside from a lady who locks the hot tub at 11pm. Our room has had countless things stop working like electricity and our ac which still struggles to work. This building was very obviously rushed to ensure it was done before people moved in, and it shows in quality. You can see the wall paper by the elevators coming off and the floors have already had to be redone in less than a year. Not to mention the fire alarm goes off countless amounts of times for no reason (3 times in one week). The amenities that were promised fall short as well. The study spaces are crammed and small. There was an espresso bar and rooftop grills that were promised that were never added. Not to mention things like the rooftop TVs never work, nor is there a way to change channels or sounds.

These issues would not even be permissible if I lived in an apartment that cost $500, let alone over 1k! I hope that students or other people who are interested in living here read these reviews and understand the downfalls of living here. We were all excited to move in at first until we actually started living here. Look into other apartments that have a proven track record of helpful management and little to no mechanical and physical issues. I understand that this is a new building, but the company is not new to student housing which is why it came as such a shock that they seem to not know anything about it.
owner_answer: Hi Nathan. Thank you for being open about your experience—your feedback helps us to further improve our services at Hub. It’s always our goal to provide the best experience possible. Please give our Management Office or the Customer Service Department a call at 512-732-1099, we'd love to get more ideas on how we  can improve. Thank you. - Taniya R. [Corporate Customer Service]

name: Hub Ann Arbor
review_text:
Have had a really good experience living in the Hub this year. First off, the new management team is really solid (I think many of the negative reviews on here are due to the old management team and also while the building was being finished at the end of construction. The Hub is a brand-new building, so there was a little bit of construction still being completed during move-in. Obviously, that is not the case anymore because the building is completed now). Any time that I have needed something fixed, management is extremely quick to respond and are very polite and courteous. Management also does a very good job of keeping the building clean and running smoothly. I have only had good interactions with them.

Second, the rooms are very nice. Room floor plans are well designed, and the appliances are of good quality. I love my room because it has a beautiful view of Ann Arbor along with a large balcony (some rooms have larger balconies than others, so if this is important to you, make sure you view your room before signing the lease). I’m not aware of many other apartments in Ann Arbor with balconies like this, so this was a huge plus for me. Another thing I like about the rooms is that they come with blackout shades, which keep the rooms really dark. I also got a parking spot with my unit. The garage is very convenient because it is underneath the building and the driveway doesn’t lead out to a busy street, unlike many of the other Ann Arbor apartment buildings. If you have a bigger car, it might be a good idea to request that your parking spot be on the first parking garage level because getting down to the second level might be tight.

Third, the facilities in the Hub are better than any of the other apartments in Ann Arbor I have seen. The Hub has a large rooftop hot tub, steam room, nice workout facility, study room and a pool table. Along with the hot tub, the roof also has a great view of downtown Ann Arbor and The Big House, grills, large/comfy chairs and two fire pits (loved the fire pits during the fall season).

Fourth, the Hub is in a fantastic location. It is close to campus and is also near many of the best restaurants and bars in Ann Arbor (you will probably have a lot of friends over because of this!). Living around South U will put you closer to some of your classes, but it will certainly disadvantage you when it comes to food options and nightlife. I have lived in Ann Arbor for six years and this is by far the most convenient location I have lived in. Another aspect I enjoy about this location is that it is easy to escape from Ann Arbor and hangout by the river or run/hike trails, as they are less than a mile away.

Now that the one year learning curve has been surpassed, I think future residents will have a really good living experience here.

Our apartment has been barged into twice by staff members/maintenance without notice and without consent for non-emergent reasons. When addressed, management made up excuses as to why we were never informed about another drawer being delivered and said it was justified because they knocked. We don't feel safe in our own apartment because our privacy means nothing to management.

Even though it's brand new, 90% of the construction being done now should have been done before move in. The fire pits were just fine when I moved in on Aug. 1 but have been blocked off and "under construction" for a month and a half now. I haven't seen anyone working on them in weeks. On the rare occasion where work is actually done, they drill and hammer before 8am which is absurd.

The floor in the lobby was torn up and no email was sent to residents letting us know that we couldn't go out the front door all week. The manager promised to me personally to send out an email to all residents when the floor was going to be torn up.

All of the above have been addressed with management, nothing has been done, and it is unacceptable. We are taken advantage of because we're college students. If this were a building for adults with full time jobs, this would absolutely not be tolerated.

I have never written a review before because I have never felt that it was necessary until now. I'm stuck here for a year blowing tons of money on a place that is not at all worth it and I hope this saves others from doing the same.

Update: I was told a year ago that all utilities would be covered except for electric. In December we got a water bill and had no idea it was coming. It is January and we just got five gas bills for August, September, October, November, and December that will be added to next months rent. Again, it was advertised to us that we would not have to pay for anything but electric.

review_text:
It has been a dream of mine to live at the HUB since it opened up, but I couldn’t afford it for a while. This year I saved up and decided to move in here with my job and school being within 1 min walk. I came in with very high expectations and that lead to disappointment.

Cons:
- Main attraction for me was a steam room, I was ready to pay my last money just to have a steam room access since its so deeply rooted in my cultural upbringing. Sadly in the past 8 month it has been broken 9/10 times I check. I am very sad about that.
- There are many ’stealthy’ fees that will hunt you during your stay here. Make sure to ask about all of them upfront.
- Hot tub has been under construction several times, latest one being over a month long!
- Music in the gym/elevator just turns on and off all the time which is very distracting. I have to always wear headphones when I work out. Also gym does NOT have any barbells which was a big disappointment for me.
- Many reviews here mention the noise isolation being an issue. Ditto! I hear my roommates walking in the kitchen, the bathroom and even their own spaces like they are in my room. Wakes me up at night and throws my days off quite a bit.
- Kitchen exhaust is so weak, you won’t even notice that it’s on. I called maintenance thinking it was broken, gentlemen told me this is expected and they won’t do anything about it.
- Internet is really fast, but occasionally (3-4 times a month) goes out completely for an hour or two, and as a gamer this was unacceptable. Support gets back within 24hrs telling me there is no problem or it has been resolved!
- You will be paying for 12 installments for rent but won’t be able to live there during August 🤷‍♂️

Pros:
- ⚡️Blazing-fast fiber internet! It takes 1 min to download or upload 5 Gb (very good for streaming 4k or gaming)
- 📦 Package-delivery is very professional with new self access technology!
- 🏢 The new management is very helpful and outstanding in every way!🤞
- 🔧 Stuff gets fixed almost instantly, you call the number on the fridge and the guy shows up basically.

Note to the owners: Personally I think American Campus should try putting Students before their bottom line first. This is a big trend in the past decade and it does pay off huge dividends in future. Current management at the Hub is very good but hearing “NO” so many times makes me think their hands are tied and it leaves a really bad taste in my mouth.

name: Hub Ann Arbor
review_text:
My experience at Hub was really disappointing, for several reasons. There were countless mistakes in the construction of the building that were clear oversights-I'm honestly not sure how some of these things were possibly overlooked. There is no place to park or stop in front of the building, no driveway, etc. There hasn't been a front door to the building for about 4 months, because the first one was ridiculously heavy. There wasn't recycling in the building for the first three months. Things break constantly-I have a friend who can't keep his lights on for more than 10 minutes without them shutting off. The rooftop has speakers and TV's which sounds nice, but the speakers blast pop music that you can't turn off, and I still haven't found a way to turn on or off the TV's, let alone change the channels. The promised "study space" is tiny, and really just not practical to use. There's often been no notice to residents that work is going on in the building, and there's been several mornings where I've been woken up bright and early by the sound of a power drill or a hammer banging away nearby--for any student, this isn't ideal at all, and I feel like this should be something that would have been made right by a simple notice or alert beforehand. Really simple things have gotten consistently overlooked throughout the year, and this was really surprising to see from a company that has experience operating similar properties.

The management has changed several times over the year, but no matter who is in charge of the building, they've been unresponsive and hard to reach throughout the year.

I'd also like to point out that several of the "five star" reviews of the building were written by people who also work for Hub, so I'd read those with a grain of salt.

Simply put, if you're going to spend the money that Hub charges, do so somewhere else and get what you're paying for. If you choose to live at Hub, you will not get your money's worth from the experience, as I found out throughout the year. There isn't one glaring issue, but many smaller ones that add up to what I can only describe as a frustrating experience throughout the year.

A bright spot is the maintenance team, who are awesome, responsive, and super friendly.

name: Beekman on Broadway
review_text:
Great property, BUT be willing to compromise.

I have lived here for a year, this is written BEFORE phase 2 has opened, here are my pros / cons.

PROS:
>Great entertainment options to rent out hourly for events, pool area is awesome during the summer.
>Michelle and Kaitlin are who I have interacted with most and have been able to help me out with many issues.
>New appliances, modern design, definitely an impressive space to live in overall.
>Monthly resident events often with free food and the opportunity to meet your neighbors.
>Back-up generators for when the power goes out and unfortunately this occurs semi-often in Michigan.
>Remote entry from your phone, very convenient for guests.
>Covered parking, and most of the time you park on the floor you live on (this will only be for Phase 1, not for the new building).
>Walking distance from UMICH medical school and hospital.
>Secure package room for larger mail deliveries.
>Non-smoking building ** SEE CON BELOW **

CONS:
>Nothing is included, you pay trash, electrical, gas, internet, water, parking, everything.
>For $20 a month the trash system is a J O K E, the photos attached reflect that. You will notice another review from nearly a year ago stating the exact issue with photos as well. It will not improve. AVOID living by the trash chutes at ALL cost unless you do not mind being partially blocked in I'd estimate once a month.
>Residents drive erratically in the garage. PLEASE watch children and pets when in the garage and also when driving as well because these residents do not care. Issue persisted after speed limit signs were hung, most likely will continue unless speed bumps are installed.
>Overall cleanliness of the building has decreased in the last 6 months: trash in stairwells, stains on carpets. Management will have spots cleaned if you complain but overall the entire hallways require cleaning I would say 2-3x a year professionally for the traffic it receives.
>The gym air conditioning often goes out, I think it has been out for several months at this point, it will reach nearly 80 degrees fahrenheit on some nights, management says they've tried to have it repaired but basically that means get used to it.
>Construction on phase 2 is agonizing. Streets will be blocked at random times, work will begin as early as 5:30 in the morning. If they are to develop the last parcel of land (which is fenced off currently) AVOID living anywhere your apartment window would see it because that means you will hear noise for over a year if they choose to develop that too.
> ** While the building is non-smoking, residents have a free for all after management leaves **

I have already raised all of these cons to management, it just does not improve, thus why I say be ready to compromise. Other issues have been resolved thankfully; they do listen. For $25,000 a year though, I do wish I had to compromise a little less.

If you have the opportunity to live in a high-rise in Detroit or Royal Oak etc, do it, it may even be cheaper. If you are needing to live in Ann Arbor, all things considering (though the trash issue is unacceptable) Beekman is one of 3 places I would consider living in, which is why I still do.
owner_answer:
Hi Daniel:
Thank you for your review.  We are happy that you are enjoying our resident events, appliances, and our location.  We enjoy having you as a Resident.  With regards to the cons mentioned, we do our best to maintain our building properly.  We apologize for any inconvenience you have experienced.  The concern with the trash that are experiencing stems from the weekends where the City does not collect trash on Sundays.  As you know, it is cleaned up first thing Monday mornings.  Unfortunately, it is clear some neighbors do not follow proper protocol.  The same can be said with regards to the parking garage as we have previously discussed.   We appreciate your feedback and always take it under advisement.
Thank you,
Beekman on Broadway

name: Beekman on Broadway
review_text:
Nice from the outside, but terrible noise insulation and trash disposal issues:

Having lived here for a little more than a year, while the apartments and amenities do look nice and chique from the outside, the living experience gets overshadowed by two main issues: terrible noise insulation and trash disposal issues.

1.) Noise issues

- You will be barraged to a cacophony of annoying noises throughout the week like construction, lawn mowers, garbage truck disposals, fake fire alarms, and of course, very obnoxious & loud neighbors. These walls, like most apartments, are SUPER thin. Personally, I had to constantly complain to management about marbles rolling across the floor, thumps, and loud bass music that shook and reverberated my walls, especially at later hours of the night. It took a whole ~6 months before my upstairs neighbor finally got the message to stop making obscene noises, and even then, it still happens on occasion. In the contract clause you sign, it’s one of the things that’s glossed over. Be sure to understand where your room is situated relative to the ruckus (i.e. my room is right near the lawn and construction site, so good luck trying to sleep in some days). Management has tried to alleviate and taper off the scheduling for these noises, but it’s unavoidable. The whole spiel about “concrete walls” used to help with noise insulation is an absolute joke.

2.) Trash disposal issues

- The trash chutes and disposal room become full and overflowing really quick. Come July-September, the trash chutes and hallways are ESPECIALLY filthy.  I’m assuming this is caused by the influx of neighbors who don’t know better (hopefully). A lot of inconsiderate neighbors who have no regard for keeping the public complex sanitary. People are not meant to clean after your trash.

LEARN HOW TO BREAK A BOX DOWN AND TAKE IT TO THE TRASH ROOM OR DUMPSTERS OUTSIDE.  DON’T JUST DUMP YOUR OVERFLOWING TRASH IN FRONT OF SOMEONE’S DOOR. This is one of the things management should really enforce and better orient people who first move-in.

Final thoughts:

Overall, for rent that is ~$1900-2k+ per month and DOES NOT include any amenities, Beekman charges high rent prices that rival some parts of NYC and California. Yes, the management are kind and empathetic and the amenities are nice (i.e. gated parking, gym, package room, pool).  However, I wouldn’t recommend living here unless you are absolutely dead set on it and choose a good room that’s oriented away from the noise hub. There’s definitely better and more cheaper options unless you need to live near the Medical campus or have wealth to flaunt. Plus, the rent only gets more expensive each year without any special added benefits (classic Ann Arbor housing market and zoning ordinances at play). I had to haggle to negotiate my inevitable rent price increase.

Misc. Comment
Also, as a side note, this place also attracted the crowd who feel the need to overcompensate for their "lack of personality" with flashy sport cars. Even though it’s a small sliver of residents, I feel it’s important to note that the garages are not meant for you to speed and use as a Thruxton race track circuit. People and families live here, please do not run them over.

1.	Early morning ( 4-7 a.m) harsh noises

a.	the garbage truck at ~5-7 a.m., particularly when bangs the metal garbage container to garbage truck to empty out container or when it makes a loud beeping alarm when it drives back forth
b.	 Construction which mostly starts at 7 a.m.
c.	the loud blow horn of the nearby Amtrak train at ~4:30 a.m.

2.	Unhealthy air quality due to construction outside

With the construction right outside, the air quality was unhealthy. The construction dust and debris can be smelled in both outside and inside the apartment complex.

I frequently experienced tightening of my chest when I lived here and much of it probably had to do with living around the construction dust and debris.

3.	Rude and dismissive management
Management has a mean and careless attitude towards residents. With that in mind, they’re not reliable in resolving problems residents have.

name: Beekman on Broadway
review_text:

As the construction progresses, the noise problem has improved a bit. It is less noisy, but the beeping sound is still a bit noisy before the end of the construction in the afternoon.

--------------------------------
An irritating bad environment.

The apartment itself is good, but the surrounding environment is extremely terrible, especially the NOISE problem. The beeping garbage truck dangling in front of the apartment every day before 7AM.

The residents on the south side of the apartment have never had quality sleep.

The apartment owner seemed willing to negotiate to let the garbage truck handle the garbage a few hours later, but the result of this negotiation only lasted a few days.

As a tenant, I can understand the construction requirements in front of the apartment. But why work from 7AM in the morning to 3 in the afternoon? Why can't the apartment postpone the time to give tenants a quiet morning and adequate sleep?

What's more puzzling is that all the construction machines are beeping non-stop. I do understand that this kind of large machine needs to remind people behind to pay attention to safety when reversing, but the machines on the construction site are reversing more than 60% of the time. Wouldn't these drivers drive forward? Is this to save fuel?

The soundproofing effect of the apartment itself is very poor, this kind of continuous sharp and harsh sound affects people's hearing very much and has huge torture to the tenants' nerves. If construction is necessary, why can't the apartment be installed with soundproof glass? For cost considerations, soundproof glass can be installed only for the south room.

The replies received from the email communication basically indicate that they cannot solve any problems: because the lease agreement states that there will be construction problems, so the tenant is responsible for the noise generated.

Maybe only when I make an evaluation on a publicly evaluated website like Google Maps will I get the apartment owner’s attention. But what I want is a noise solution, not "please come to my office to discuss the problem".

In addition, the air environment on the south side of the apartment is extremely poor due to construction. I don't know if the air POLLUTION is also written in the contract and the tenant is responsible for it. But people with allergies and asthma can be very uncomfortable.

Considering that the construction in front of the apartment may last for several years, I strongly do NOT recommend students and people who need work to rent this apartment.

This is the second time posting this message, the owner of the apartment or some individuals framed and deleted my last comment.

review_text:
Great experience living in Beekman on Broadway! This is a relatively new apartment in the Ann Arbor area so the rooms and most of the amenities in the building are in great condition and also up to date. I think for me, the most impressive things about this apartment are:

-	The community has a covered parking lot and it’s super convenient for residents to access their cars just steps away from their homes (basically the whole building is a combination of a parking lot and rooms, so it provides great convenience without making any noise or problems)
-	The staffs are very friendly and responsive. Lauds to the great ladies in the leasing office as well as the cool guys responsible for maintenance. They might be a little bit busy during the peak times (like August of each year when students are moving in), but still willing to help then. Most of the time, they are always there to help with any questions or problems you may have
-	The neighbors are also great people. Some of the residents are students in the university, but there are also local people working around the city. They are all very friendly and I didn’t have any unpleasant experiences with neighbors. The community holds resident events every month so one has the chance to get to know your neighbor
-	Great location on Broadway Street. Several great restaurants just across the street from the building with different styles. I really like the newly opened Plate. It’s also close to the North Campus of the university so it’s convenient to go to school even by bicycle. Of course, if you have a car, there won’t be any problems at all.
-	The amenities provided are really great. Basically, all you see on the website are actually there for you to use, not like some apartments that just put fake photos and statements

Several potential downsides of the apartment (I don’t want to use the word “cons” because personally I don’t think these things below are problems, or at least don’t bother me much)

-	I heard some people are experiencing noise problems due to the nearby construction site. I can’t speak for other people but at my unit, I didn’t experience any noise at all. Maybe with the progress on the site, the problem shouldn’t last long (at least it should be alleviated)
-	The price is indeed kind of high compared to other communities around the area. I would say it’s overall worth it, but it’s understandable that some people feel this might not be a good match for them
-	Most of the units are unfurnished, so this might cause some problems for those who just arrived in the city (or the country). But as long as you manage to get some furniture later, you can create your own sweet home. I heard the apartment also has some furnished floor plans, but not many.
-	Yeah, there are small problems with the apartment operations occasionally (like false fire alarms etc), but I can see that the management teams are trying their best to solve these problems and create a good living environment for everyone here

Anyway, I would say this is a great place to live. As a new international student who just arrive at the U.S. last year, Beekman on Broadway really provides a good home for me. I’m not affiliated with the apartment in any way and I guarantee this is my true experience. Just pay a visit to see everything for yourself if you are still in doubt LOL!

Overall, I had a good experience renting at Ann Arbor Woods. Here are some of the pros and cons I found about living here:

Pros:
1. Location - Close to downtown (1.5 miles) and close to stores/shopping on Washtenaw. Also had public transit right on Medford Road.
2. Maintenance was usually pretty timely to respond to concerns and fixed them properly.
3. Office staff was always available and very friendly/helpful when I went in.
4. Even though the washer/dryer was a shared basement unit, I never had issues doing laundry.

Cons:
1. The apartments are VERY old for the price you pay. Rent went up as I was leaving, and even though I left for work reasons, it would have been hard to pay their asking price for the age and condition of the apartments.

2. With apartment age comes a lot of minor annoyances that you should be prepared to deal with.

3. Winter grounds maintenance could be better. The parking lot was often left unplowed after snow storms.

4. Baseboard heat did not work very well or properly and the pipes in the basement vibrated and squeaked below my unit.

Overall, I would recommend these apartments to a friend. They could really stand to be updated if the prices continue to increase, but all in all a good place to rent.

Hayman made many cheap attempts at luring people to sign leases for “luxury apartment living”, but their ploys only left current tenants to deal with increased rent, new services we didn’t ask for (but had to pay for), paying for utilities, and unnecessary updates while ignoring what really needs updating.
They rolled out a “reserved parking” plan where tenants could pay extra for the few closest spots to their apartment building, but new tenants didn’t realize that those spots were once free!  Seriously, I was not going to pay extra each month for “reserved parking” when I was able to park there for free before!
The maintenance and upkeep I saw during my time there under Hayman’s management were not impressive. The lawn and landscaping schedule was pushed from Wednesday mornings to Saturdays, so we were woken up early every weekend to the loud motors of mowers and blowers because the truck made its permenant parking space right outside our apartment.
As we were moving out, there were some coats of paint sloppily slapped on the walls of our building’s hallway. In the warmer months, trash sat on the grass for multiple days in a row before someone came to pick it up.
I really enjoyed all the perks of living at Ann Arbor Woods in the beginning. And I do agree that it is a fabulous location (right behind Trader Joe’s, easy access to downtown and Washtenaw) but I was very disappointed in the quality of management that came with the shift in ownership.

name: Ann Arbor Woods
review_text:
Before Ann Arbor Woods was bought out by Hayman last year, this used to be a pretty nice, somewhat affordable option. Since they've taken over, my rent has gone up about $300/month. My one bedroom apartment, (that is by no means "luxury"), is about $1300/month now. Nothing is included, and there’s really no amenities whatsoever.

In addition to rent increases, they stated charging for water, gas, pest removal, some sewer fee, storm drain fee, of course some kind of really important admin fee, and they've enforced a mandatory $25/month garbage removal fee where everyone has a trash can that sits and stinks in the hallway and an outside company comes and picks it up. Cool, if you're handicap or elderly, but not for the majority of residents who are 20-30 year olds and have working legs and live on a fixed income. Most people don't even seem to use it. So it's just wasted money for a company that they probably have some sort of deal with. Might be a nice option to have people voluntarily OPT in for. Aside from the unnecessary trash can thing, all of the other charges were already included in my previous rent amount before Hayman. I could *maybe* understand starting to charge for the monthly utilities but NOT jacking the rent up as well. They obviously don't care about the interests of the residents here.

They've taken away at least 15-20 parking spots. We already had covered parking spots available to rent out, but now there's several "reserved" UNCOVERED spots that you have to pay for. No one pays for them because it's stupid. Even tho no one seems to be paying for/using them, they're still there months later so now we just have that many less spots to park in.

I'm sure part of the huge rent increase has gone to gutting and re-doing the leasing office, tho! Now the leasing office looks like the entry-way of a tanning salon. So glad I'm contributing to that.

They also redid the landscaping by tearing up the grass and putting a bunch of rocks and boulders. Nice?

On top of all this, every person I've dealt with in the leasing office has been extremely short and rude. Absolutely zero knowledge/sense of customer service. When I've called/visited them to inquire about anything, (like my maintenance request that has gone un-acknowledged for weeks) instead of them maybe apologizing and finding a way to resolve the issue, I've gotten attitude as if I'm in the wrong, or like I'm imposing on them somehow. I'm sure working in an environment like that can be annoying sometimes because you're dealing with the sometimes unhappy resident, but I think they need to realize that that's literally their job. To help. When you make 100 dumb, mandatory changes to people's living environment (many of whom have lived here for 5+ years), they're going to probably be a little disgruntled about some of them.

The maintenance guys seem nice, when I happen to see/hear from them. Maintenance requests can go weeks without any acknowledgement. The only way to get a response is by reaching out to the office 5+ times AFTER submitting an online request.

Want happy residents?

1. Don't jack their rent up and give them useless "updates" as a return. The new door numbers now look like cheesy clip-art that should be on a kindergarten classroom door. The old ones were 100% fine.
2. Just be somewhat friendly/nice/understanding to your residents. Ask them what they want before making expensive changes that nobody wants.

And that's it.

Having one free hotdog party a year as some kind of "resident appreciation" doesn't make up for rude staff members or your extreme pricing increases.

This is a good option to rent, and - given the price - probably the best in town. Here are the pros and cons from my perspective.

PROS:
-It is an inexpensive, yet fully renovated unit. I haven't been able to find any renovated 2 bedroom apartment at a price even nearly as close as the one I am paying here. The apartment is completely renovated - from the floorboards and bathroom tiles, to kitchen appliances and cupboards; it looks and feels absolutely great. This is a huge plus, given how high the rent in Ann Arbor is.
- With the odd party, it has been fairly quiet during the night, so one is able to rest (not so quiet during the day, though)
- It is relatively close to campus (about a 15-minute bike ride, 20-25 minutes on the bus, which is comparable to Woodbury Gardens where I used to rent for 4 years prior to moving here).
- The proximity of the nearby public park is great if you have a pet.
- They do have a quick and responsive maintenance
- It is pet friendly.

CONS
-The biggest issue: my unit is above the laundry room and there's a non-stop ambient noise; in addition, you can feel strong smell of detergent if the window is open. The noise can only be heard in the living room but it bad enough for me to need to watch TV using headphones. This was NOT made clear when I decided to rent here. Had it been made clear, I would not have chosen the unit I am currently renting.
-It is definitely not as quiet as my previous rental community, Woodbury Gardens. AA Woods is a lot cheaper, though - the rent is $700 lower, so this is expected as you get a different type of tenant/neighbour, in particular, many more undergraduate students vs. professionals compared to my previous community.
-Unlike Woodbury Gardens and The Ponds at Georgetown, Ann Arbor Woods does not provide ANY dog amenities, despite charging the same - $30 fee. There are no dog waste stations, dog waste bags or a dog park. So you feel you are being charged a pet fee without anything provided for your pet. I do not mind too much, though, since the rent is very low considering what you are getting.

name: Ann Arbor Woods
review_text:
Take the negative reviews about new management, Hayman, seriously. They took over last summer, 2018, and are flipping the place.  I received an informal note on my door stating I would need to reapply.  When I went to inquire, the staff that Hayman originally had in place were very confused, and answers were vague.  It was at that point  I learned of the hefty  increase in rent to come. Nothing formal in writing was ever sent stating what the rent would be, nor what month to month would be if one didn't sign a new lease. I couldn't get a straight answer. They've since sent in  a second set of staff.  I've talked to two of the three and they were both very rude, and simply unpleasant to deal with. Appears to be a scam tactic and on purpose to drive current residents out.  I only just learned today, 3/24/2019,  that they will now be charging for "all utilities" when I dared to go talk with staff to inquire about status of uncompleted maintenance requests. They could not answer how they will determine what renters will pay.
This is the trend of course for places where the economy is good. Big companies come in, buy out complexes, and jack up the rents. Unfortunately, A2 is at this point. The way it works, but the unethical way in which Hayman is going about it is very bothersome.
I've lived here for close to twenty years. AAWs is one of the oldest, still existing complexes in A2.  It is a fantastic location.  However, the buildings are falling apart due to age.  There are constant maintenance issues and it's not unusual to see maintenance folks scampering around loudly.  Out of fairness to the last management, Slavik, there was an honest attempt to try to fix up the place. They started remodeling kitchens and some bathrooms as residents moved out. They also fixed balconies, and did some repairs on concrete, and re-landscaped the place. This increased effort started  about five years ago after city inspectors started coming through.  The maintenance staff took notes for every apartment a few weeks prior regarding what needed to be fixed. They said they'd do it soon, but the inspectors must not have scheduled my place, as those repairs never took place.
Hayman's claim is that they will be upgrading the apartments. All I've really seen is new  paint slapped on the walls sloppily by shoddy workers. Much of what you see  now was done by Slavik.  I've seen no real attention paid to more major problems such as leaky plumbing, and heat problems. Maintenance of snow and ice this past winter was poor.  For my place alone, my ceiling has been damaged three times due to leaking plumbing from above.  My heat has never worked correctly, my A/C pre-dates my move in, there is a spot on one wall that is crumbling, and the glaze on my tub has worn thin in one spot. All reported, all ignored.
I've put up with all of this as the rent was well below other apartments. There were also many middle aged long term tenants here and it was a very friendly, nice community.  Most have left  as they learned of rent increase, utilities, and increased noise level by inconsiderate workers.
I hope I'm wrong, and that Hayman will actually fix this place up big time, but all it is now is sloppily done cosmetic for looks things.  In my opinion what this place really needs is a total gutting, or a tear down and rebuild. You can do better for the amount of money Hayman wants, and believe me, you won't want to deal with the staff after you move in.
Could be the staff are simply burnt out already, as that has been the trend here.  Staff never have stayed long, probably due to abnormally large amount of maintenance requests and upkeep. There are nicer places to work without the headaches. I wish them well and hope they can be nicer, more honest,  in the future. You'd think Hayman Company would have sent in staff that know how to do it right. As for me, time to follow the lead of others and leave. I can find better for what I've heard the price  will be from others. Note too, one of few positive reviews is by the current leasing agent. Unbelievable!

Customer service and the satisfaction of our guests are our top community priorities. We do hope that you will give us the opportunity to serve you again in the future.

name: Ann Arbor Woods
review_text:
So I needed to find an affordable place to move to almost immediately after being hired for a job in Ann Arbor. I live alone in a 1B1B on the 2nd floor in a motel style building near the leasing office.

Good things I have to say about Ann Arbor woods is that near work, the bus stops near by are convenient for getting to work (I have to pay for parking to go to work so taking the bus for free using my employee ID is great), and apparently the rent ($995 for rent alone and other charges making a total of around $1000-$1100 a month) I pay is considered "cheap" for Ann Arbor. There's trash removal right in front of my door so I don't have to go all the way down to throw out my trash which is nice.

I was spoiled I guess because the apartment I lived in before was half the rent cheaper and came fully furnished with a in-unit washer and dryer which I can understand because Ann Arbor is a more expensive place to live in but for the price I pay, I expected my apartment here to be...better.

PLEASE READ

Some bad things about my experience here so far since moving in only 6 months ago...

The motel style building I live in can be bothersome. There is a walk-way right in front of my 2 large windows in my bed room and living room which makes it difficult to have my blinds open to have natural light when people can walk by and see what I'm doing in my apartment so I feel like I have no privacy. I will ask for a different building when my lease comes to a near end probably.

When I first moved in, the apartment was HOT. I moved in near the beginning of summer but it was still somewhat cold where I didn't need to turn on the AC but I did. I was told by maintenance after making about 2 or 3 complaints about it that there is a pipe that runs through my unit that causes the heat and that they'v known about it for a while but haven't done anything about it. With my complaint, I was asked "did you try turning on the AC?" I don't want to waste energy doing that when it's still cool outside but the heat is coming from my building.

The AC unit is only in the living room.

There's no thermostat in my apartment so I never know what the temp in my unit is.

The blades for the blinds in the living room don't match each other and they break easily from me turning them only a few times since moving in (I don't turn them often since because of above mentioned privacy issue). Since they are different lengths and widths, the blades run into each other and don't turn so they get stuck and break...

My bedroom door frame is wonky so when it's closed there's a noticeable gap.

There's no counter space in the bathroom and the toilet paper thing is placed in a bad place where it's difficult to reach and near the corner of the sink so when the sink gets wet, water drips off and onto the toilet paper.

I'm paying for "pest control" or whatever but I've never lived in an apartment where I found this many bugs. My old apartment didn't have a bug problem like I've noticed here. HUGE BUGS and I've noticed my apartment is prone to fruit flies. Never had a problem like this before anywhere else I lived.

There have been times where I've tried to visit the leasing office to try and speak to someone about these issues but even during business hours, the office would be locked with no one inside so it seems difficult to get a hold on someone.

These might sound like small things but if I'm paying $1000-ish I should have some of this not be a problem.

I’ve been at The George since 2019. I’ve lived through no less than three different property management firms. I think I’ve earned the right to an opinion.

I’ve changed my ratings for the property from a “1” to a “3” and now a “5”. I’ll be blunt, The George is not cheap. My expectations are set accordingly. My main concerns have been management of the common areas such as the pool and landscaping, the mail system and trash. Further, for the money, I’ve been astonished at how little has been done to make me feel like a customer (ie a privilege) vs an anonymous face (a necessary endurance required to collect rent). It’s a pity. The property itself is extremely nice. New lofts are going in. I’d argue it should be a contender for the top spot in A2. However, those common services were / are designed woefully under capacity for the 249 apartments here. The property management companies have historically expected the maintenance team (a whopping 2 people) to muscle through the capacity problems manually, but even at 70 hour weeks, the problem(s) is(are) too big. That’s where the new community manager comes into play.

I feel a wee bit guilty, but I cornered the new community manager for some “coaching” several weeks back. Poor thing, it was about 45 minutes of it. I’d say she took it professionally and empathetically. She was attentive. Solid customer management skills. She made several promises to improve the situation. In return, I agreed to a clean slate review here if, and only if, I saw positive change brewing. Well, I have and hence have penned this review. I’m optimistic the changes I’m seeing will make a difference. I’m particularly delighted with the scrutiny around the mail system. Specifically, holding the carriers accountable. That’s been a real thorn in everyone’s heel. Communications from the community management office are improving (some of the prior communications were just embarrassing). Little things like trash pickup are improving. And so on, but that noise makes a big difference to the tenants. The guys paying the bills.

Is everything suddenly resolved and humming along? No. There’s much to be done. My “5” rating is as much about renewed confidence as it is about sustained change. Every community will have its challenges. Full stop. It’s how those challenges are tackled that counts. It’s my confidence in the new team, + guys like Moe (maintenance leader) who’s been around a few years like me, that are behind my “5”.

Now, if only we could arrange a Korean taco truck…………..
